author: Primrose Riordan
title: The new ways politicians are targeting you online
text:
Liberal MP Sarah Henderson and Malcolm Turnbull in Geelong on Wednesday morning. Twitter Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Malcolm Turnbull's cross-social media blogging of his train trip to Geelong, the same trip Speaker Bronwyn Bishop took in a helicopter, has thrown into the spotlight the increasingly sophisticated ways politicians are using social media to gain voters.
Last week NSW Premier Mike Baird made a major policy announcement via Twitter video, about GST reform, which reached 270,000 people, with 70,000 actually watching it.
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten (and his staff) have discovered Periscope, the app that lets you broadcast a live video stream from your mobile to anyone who wants to watch, and are filming every press conference with wild abandon.
Meanwhile, corporations have caught on. Facebook for example has beefed up its government and politics team to pitch new features and ways to collect donors to US Presidential campaigns desperate to extend their reach.
If our health system is to survive, we need our political leaders to bring solutions to the table. I'll go first.
 https://t.co/JiAO5eeFKF
— Mike Baird (@mikebairdMP) July 19, 2015 Experts say the impression of immediacy can bring life to staid announcements, while maintaining control - ensuring no Malcolm Tucker-esque dressing downs follow.
"Using Twitter, and especially video, is the ideal way for political leaders to get an unfiltered message out to the electorate straight from the horse's mouth, while also demonstrating a bit of personality," Twitter partnerships manager Flip Prior said.
Pollies can gain kudos online by showing they are human, something Phillip Ruddock has put on display by sharing his Fitbit results and old "flashback Friday" photos, including a saucy number of the Father of the House at a 70s Hawaiian party.
And what if you need to duck political damage from your own party in your electorate? Social media's great for that too.
 I've never supported the Shenhua mine. I think it is ridiculous that you would have a major mine in the midst of...
Posted by Barnaby Joyce Member for New England on Tuesday, 7 July 2015 The medium accommodates less-than-official sprays at both colleagues and the opposition, such as Malcolm Turnbull's train trip, popular with an authenticity-craving public.
Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce's "world gone mad" Facebook post , Reclaim Australia supporter George Christensen's offer to fight a commenter on his Facebook page as well as various Liberal frontbenchers live tweet-heckling of the ALP conference are even more examples.
Driven by media disruption and the public's hunger for more personal connection with leaders, Australian politicians are more starting to see their digital footprint as vital professional tool, and less as "electronic graffiti".
Seeking to control and maximise social media's impact, Mr Baird employs former advertising creative, Tony Story as his own head of digital media, and the federal Liberal party has a small team of digital wizards.
From the Memory Hole - Tony Abbott on the Speaker and Parliamentary standards... pic.twitter.com/zxpyawZNW0
— Tim Watts (@TimWattsMP) July 18, 2015 Of course not quite every politician has caught up with the wind change.
Political parties as publishers The Labor party have taken a step further opening their own social news outlet, the Labor Herald, the fruit of a three-year-old strategy led in part by the ALP's head of digital, Skye Laris.
​Not only was the site launched at the party's national conference by Opposition leader Bill Shorten, Daniel Andrews' election campaign mastermind and advertising executive, Darren Moss was also there to offer support .
#fbf None of this #SydneyWeather at @FedYL #Hawaiian night in QLD, '73. #auspol #summernights #flashbackfriday pic.twitter.com/dTmyceDsz0
— Philip Ruddock (@philipruddockmp) July 17, 2015 Editor Alex Brooks responded to the website's rejection from the press gallery by blasting it for being stuck in the past, saying now "political parties are also becoming publishers".
Starting with just two staff, and $40,000 in crowdfunding, within their first week they gained more than 4500 Facebook likes, their tweets got 're-tweeted' by journalists , and they had 8000 views on the site on one day, according to Labor sources.
Queensland University of Technology digital media professor Axel Bruns , who has been watching the site, said it "remains to be seen" if it is journalism and if it will work, while those behind the website insist however, they run no Pravda with a journalist as an editor and plans to also publish critical content.
But politicians be warned, as magazine Junkee pointed out , in this new dawn of correctly crafted messages and smiley posts there is still a fine line between fun and clunky.
